newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Calm dollar keeps lid on volatilities.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Calm dollar keeps lid on volatilities.

text.p: Implied volatilities for dollar-pair options were little changed from Friday as spot dollar hovered around 1.73 marks, options traders said.
Market participants on Monday morning continued to adopt strategies anticipating further gains in the dollar because of interest rate differentials, they said.

Several sources said one such transaction was executed this morning in dollar/mark. The buyer was said to have purchased $500 million in one-year 1.73 dollar calls before the spot dollar brushed against the level to post a new 37-month high at midday.
The presence of willing sellers blunted the impact of the large trade on volatility, said a trader for a European bank.
Implied volatility for one-year dollar/mark was 9.4/9.6 percent, about 0.1 point lower than on Friday.
One-month volatility was unchanged at 9.1/9.3 percent. Earlier in the day, one-month was slightly lower before the dollar pushed above 1.73 marks.
The next important level for dollar/mark will be 1.75, options traders said.

Support for the dollar should continue to stem from expectations for further short-term interest rate hikes in the U.S., making low-delta dollar calls attractive, said Soma Rao, first vice president and options sales manager for Smith Barney Inc.
Risk reversals, the put-call pricing differential, stayed skewed slightly in favor of mark puts. One-month 25-delta risk reversals stood at 0.1/0.4.
Near term, however, worries about the stability of the U.S. stock market after last week's steep fall may continue to drag on the dollar, Rao said.
After soaring to a 56-month high against the yen last week, dollar/yen was lagging dollar/mark because of sales of mark/yen, said a second European bank trader.
The dollar this morning was maintaining a bid above 126.00 yen but was unable to muster momentum to retest last week's high above 127.00.
One-year dollar/yen volatility was virtually unchanged at 10.5/10.6 percent late morning. One-month dollar/yen was 9.4/9.6 percent, down 0.1 point.
